Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild brings up a general question about navigating a new phase of their life.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: A ballot measure affecting their block closes in two hours at the nearby polling place.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, the sample ballot open in front of me, pen in hand, reading over the measure that would affect our block. The polling place was just a few blocks away, but it would close in two hours. I knew how important it was to participate, to have my voice heard as a citizen. Just then, my granddaughter walked in, her face uncertain. She hesitated, then asked, “Grandpa, how do you know when it’s the right time to take a big step in life?” I could see she needed more than a quick answer—she needed my full attention, my stories, my wisdom. But the clock was ticking, and I felt the weight of my civic duty pressing on me. I wanted to be the grandparent she needed, to guide her through this moment, but I also felt the responsibility to my neighbors and community. My heart tugged in two directions, torn between the call to nurture and the call to participate.
